Politics And Commitments
The conservative tide which we all
despaired over back in November has
brought some fruitful changes at Hopkins--although the changes might not make
the new regime too happy. We're pleased
to report a real surge in political activity
among students since then which, if not
entirely constructive, has at least served to
remind us that we live in a world, and not
just a campus.
Even in the Marge Mareck case, limited
solely to campus issues, students took an
especially active part in questioning how
their world was ordered. On broader
issues—the El Salvador resolution and a
proposed fast for world hunger--we've seen
a gratifying rebirth of interest in ideas
beyond next week's midterms.

Two questions arise about the new
trend. First, how sincere will our interests
in, say, the El Salvador issue be after we
pass a simple resolution? Second, are we
reverting to a kind of late-sixties liberalism,
feigning awareness, but actually accomplishing nothing?
We'd like to think that the new awareness is more than just a passing reaction to
chest-thumping statements from Mr. Haig
and increased military advertising in the
News-Letter.
Real political interest involves commitment on a deeper level. It's
not enough to say you think changes can
be made--you have to think hard about
your protests, formulate paths of action,
and keep talking.

Exploring The Port Of Baltimore
by

David Newman Et Daisy C. Taylor

You've heard that there's some place downtown
where those big cargo boats come in. But when you go
to Harborplace on Saturday afternoons, it's really
puzzling. Traffic must be slack because you don't see
any ships aside from the Constitution and a few paddle
boats. There are a few nautical trappings--the lifesavers
strung along the railing, and the seagulls--but you expected to see at least a few weatherbeaten seamen buying
souvenirs at the Embraceable Zoo or scarfing down
oysters at Phillip's.
Maybe you shrug it off, denying that Baltimore
consists of anything more than bars, a few stores, and
the campus you are heading back to. But you could
have adventured south, down past Hanover Street's
endless line of marble steps and Perma-stone, down past
a small park where the man, sitting dejectedly on a bench
is actually a Maltese sea captain in search of a pay
phone to call home. You begin to see some Maritime
taverns, places like the Dry Dock Inn, the French Quarter, and the Top Deck.
Vinally you reach the water at the Port Covington piers. The wind blows, peppering your face with
coal dust. Rusted metal warehouses, trapezoidal yards,
and rickety cranes suggest an old Mannix set. It is quiet.
You walk out on the pier, and watch the Hellenic Valor,
a sleek new freighter the size of Gilman quad, heading
across the harbor.
You drive slowly around the harbor's rim,
watching the Hellenic Valor as it steams toward a dock.
You reach Dtuidalk terminal. Time is money here in a big
way. Truck traffic moves quickly through the streets of
this industrial town between 3200 Toyotas and walls of
stacked metal box containers that hold fur coats and air
conditioners. You wait to cross the street to the wharf

leaning against the smooth white walls of a two-story vat
of molasses. Even though it's so flat down here that a
loose tire will roll forever on its own momentum, you
can't see even a shadow of downtown Baltimore's
skyscrapers, only a 10-minute drive away. But that
other place might as well be a stage front city. Without
the port, Baltimore would not exist.
The port, whose founding in 1706 predates that
of the city by 23 years, now brings in $3 billion or 10
percent of the gross state product of Maryland. It is also
the ultimate source of more than 170,000 jobs, one out
of every 10 in the state.
As Hopkins comprises more than just one campus or facility, the port of Baltimore includes 13 terniinals stretching over a 45-mile shoreline. Some of these
are owned and operated by the Maryland Port Administration (MPA), a division of the state Department of
Transportation, others by private firms like Bethlehem
Steel. As landlord the MPA leases whole terminals or

certain storage space in them to private shipping companies.
The Dundalk Marine Terminal is by far the
largest of these, covering 550 acres and serving 50
tenants. Some of the other terminals--Locust Point,
Clinton Street, and Hawkins Point--have also been
"modernized;" that is, they are adapted to handle large
amounts of container freight in a hurry. Other terminals, like Port Covington and Canton, remain less needed
and are plagued by problems with maintenance, pilfering, and in the case of Canton, prostitution on the docks.
At these lesser terminals ships lay up for repairs or to
load grain and coal--occasionally still using obsolete
loading gadgets which resemble burnt out roller coasters.
Seaman who land here are confronted with a hellish
landscape.
All terminals do not unload and store the same
kinds of freight. Dundalk specializes in container
cargo--big metal boxes which can be used interchangeably as truck trailers, train cars, and ship's cargo. It only
takes a few hours to load or unload a container ship,and
ships often come and go in a day at Dundalk. Other
kinds of cargo, usually referred to as "bulk cargo,"
involve everything from livestock to fresh fruit--one
terminal handles fruit only.
Aside from the resources that a terminal needs
for running its business and servicing its tenants(such as
customs officers, divers to recover sunken goods, maintenance and mechanics people, and the ever-present
longshoremen), there are organizations in the city
working in conjunction with the port authorities to help
foreign seamen find their bearings in Baltimore. Some
provide for special needs, such as the Mission to Chinese
Seamen or the Norwegian Seamen's Church. There are
also groups with religious backing that provide more
general aid and information.
In essence, the port is a nexus where elements of
commerce and production, usually separated into their
own factories, offices, or countries, come together.
Between terminal manager George Jones of Dundalk,for
example, and first officer Antonio Logothetis of the
Greek ship Mariam, exist a myriad of people who each
do their own jobs by their own rules for their own bosses. There are rules and boundaries set up to handle the
constant interchange of seemingly unlike elements. The
mix produces a subtle tension that permeates the terminal atmosphere.

Politics And Commitments
The conservative tide which we all
despaired over back in November has
brought some fruitful changes at Hopkins--although the changes might not make
the new regime too happy. We're pleased
to report a real surge in political activity
among students since then which, if not
entirely constructive, has at least served to
remind us that we live in a world, and not
just a campus.
Even in the Marge Mareck case, limited
solely to campus issues, students took an
especially active part in questioning how
their world was ordered. On broader
issues—the El Salvador resolution and a
proposed fast for world hunger--we've seen
a gratifying rebirth of interest in ideas
beyond next week's midterms.

Two questions arise about the new
trend. First, how sincere will our interests
in, say, the El Salvador issue be after we
pass a simple resolution? Second, are we
reverting to a kind of late-sixties liberalism,
feigning awareness, but actually accomplishing nothing?
We'd like to think that the new awareness is more than just a passing reaction to
chest-thumping statements from Mr. Haig
and increased military advertising in the
News-Letter.
Real political interest involves commitment on a deeper level. It's
not enough to say you think changes can
be made--you have to think hard about
your protests, formulate paths of action,
and keep talking.

David Newman Et Daisy C. Taylor

You've heard that there's some place downtown
where those big cargo boats come in. But when you go
to Harborplace on Saturday afternoons, it's really
puzzling. Traffic must be slack because you don't see
any ships aside from the Constitution and a few paddle
boats. There are a few nautical trappings--the lifesavers
strung along the railing, and the seagulls--but you expected to see at least a few weatherbeaten seamen buying
souvenirs at the Embraceable Zoo or scarfing down
oysters at Phillip's.
Maybe you shrug it off, denying that Baltimore
consists of anything more than bars, a few stores, and
the campus you are heading back to. But you could
have adventured south, down past Hanover Street's
endless line of marble steps and Perma-stone, down past
a small park where the man, sitting dejectedly on a bench
is actually a Maltese sea captain in search of a pay
phone to call home. You begin to see some Maritime
taverns, places like the Dry Dock Inn, the French Quarter, and the Top Deck.
Vinally you reach the water at the Port Covington piers. The wind blows, peppering your face with
coal dust. Rusted metal warehouses, trapezoidal yards,
and rickety cranes suggest an old Mannix set. It is quiet.
You walk out on the pier, and watch the Hellenic Valor,
a sleek new freighter the size of Gilman quad, heading
across the harbor.
You drive slowly around the harbor's rim,
watching the Hellenic Valor as it steams toward a dock.
You reach Dtuidalk terminal. Time is money here in a big
way. Truck traffic moves quickly through the streets of
this industrial town between 3200 Toyotas and walls of
stacked metal box containers that hold fur coats and air
conditioners. You wait to cross the street to the wharf

leaning against the smooth white walls of a two-story vat
of molasses. Even though it's so flat down here that a
loose tire will roll forever on its own momentum, you
can't see even a shadow of downtown Baltimore's
skyscrapers, only a 10-minute drive away. But that
other place might as well be a stage front city. Without
the port, Baltimore would not exist.
The port, whose founding in 1706 predates that
of the city by 23 years, now brings in $3 billion or 10
percent of the gross state product of Maryland. It is also
the ultimate source of more than 170,000 jobs, one out
of every 10 in the state.
As Hopkins comprises more than just one campus or facility, the port of Baltimore includes 13 terniinals stretching over a 45-mile shoreline. Some of these
are owned and operated by the Maryland Port Administration (MPA), a division of the state Department of
Transportation, others by private firms like Bethlehem
Steel. As landlord the MPA leases whole terminals or

certain storage space in them to private shipping companies.
The Dundalk Marine Terminal is by far the
largest of these, covering 550 acres and serving 50
tenants. Some of the other terminals--Locust Point,
Clinton Street, and Hawkins Point--have also been
"modernized;" that is, they are adapted to handle large
amounts of container freight in a hurry. Other terminals, like Port Covington and Canton, remain less needed
and are plagued by problems with maintenance, pilfering, and in the case of Canton, prostitution on the docks.
At these lesser terminals ships lay up for repairs or to
load grain and coal--occasionally still using obsolete
loading gadgets which resemble burnt out roller coasters.
Seaman who land here are confronted with a hellish
landscape.
All terminals do not unload and store the same
kinds of freight. Dundalk specializes in container
cargo--big metal boxes which can be used interchangeably as truck trailers, train cars, and ship's cargo. It only
takes a few hours to load or unload a container ship,and
ships often come and go in a day at Dundalk. Other
kinds of cargo, usually referred to as "bulk cargo,"
involve everything from livestock to fresh fruit--one
terminal handles fruit only.
Aside from the resources that a terminal needs
for running its business and servicing its tenants(such as
customs officers, divers to recover sunken goods, maintenance and mechanics people, and the ever-present
longshoremen), there are organizations in the city
working in conjunction with the port authorities to help
foreign seamen find their bearings in Baltimore. Some
provide for special needs, such as the Mission to Chinese
Seamen or the Norwegian Seamen's Church. There are
also groups with religious backing that provide more
general aid and information.
In essence, the port is a nexus where elements of
commerce and production, usually separated into their
own factories, offices, or countries, come together.
Between terminal manager George Jones of Dundalk,for
example, and first officer Antonio Logothetis of the
Greek ship Mariam, exist a myriad of people who each
do their own jobs by their own rules for their own bosses. There are rules and boundaries set up to handle the
constant interchange of seemingly unlike elements. The
mix produces a subtle tension that permeates the terminal atmosphere.

An obsolete loading gadget at old Port Covington.
Logothetis has fond memories of the ports where
his boat stopped for the longest time. When he comes
into Baltimore he goes straight to Greek-town and later,
to the zoo, where he takes pictures to add to an extensive collection. It is hard for him to separate Baltimore
as a port from other ports; the American ports, he says,
are not much different from their Western European
counterparts.
What he does see as different is the economy
here: "everyone works. In other countries there is a
problem with work. Sometimes you'd pray for work."
When he started in 1961, he couldn't afford shoes and
death from starvation was a problem on his native island
in the Aegean Sea. His father was a seaman, so at 19,
Logothetis also turned to the sea to make a living for
his family; his first wages were $30 a month. Logothetis
says that young Greeks no longer go to the sea. "Now
they go to the universities, now they become engineers,"
he explains a bit remorsefully. "I'd go that way too if!
was starting out today."
The 32-man crew of the Mariam consists mainly
of Indians, Filipinos, and South Americans, all seeking
relief from economic hardships at home, as Logothetis
once was. Though he feels a bond of common experience with these people, he cannot know "how they
think." Sometimes, during the conflicts that come up,
he has to keep stability, breaking up fights and dismissing rowdies at the next port. On deck Logothetis' eyes
take in the whole ship's activities in one sharp glance.
There are only a few crew members dotting the expanse
of rusted deck, carrying coils or adjusting valves.
Logothetits tells of a fight he broke up on
board. One of the men had a knife, he said. He pointed
overhead as he explained how they struggled on the
bridge deck until one fell off.
There are four Latin American women on the
Mariam, all of whom work in the mess hall. Logothetis is
impressed with them. "They are strong women," he
says, making a fist, "and they are able to handle the
work well."
Because everything is counted or measured at
sea,(hours, days,food, space, cargo), the ship's layout is
spare and clean. The linoleum hallways and unornamented gray-green walls all shine. In the officers' mess,
all the tables are set with pressed white tablecloths.
Naturally there is an economy of space that keeps the
visitor aware of being aboard a ship, even though -the
floors are as steady as if on land. Everyone on the ship
wears the same clothes—most of them American-bought
because they're cheaper here-flannels, longjohris, and
coveralls. The captain is indistinguishable from the deck
hands except for his age. Indeed, the uniformity of
clothing demonstrates the maxim "form follows function." Everyone except for the mess duty works the
same hours. Logothetis, second in command to the
captain, still must oversee the nuts-and-bolts work,from
general safety to painting and scraping.
Logothetis has a large sitting room furnished
with a banquet, table, desk, book shelves—and Miss
January, who hangs on her nail over the desk.
The place has the look of a dorm room. It is,
after all, a temporary living place. Seamen will sign a
work contract for a period of months and then live off
the money they make for several months before taking
on work aboard another ship. Logothetis has worked for 13 months without a break and has a nine-month
vacation coming up. He plans to work only 6 months
next time.
